title: Recipes
content: Recipes created during the Pivotal FedEx GSI Modernization engagement

title: Deploy Cookbook to Pcf
content:
Prerequisite  cf CLI Hugo  Install instructions cf CLI  Install cf CLI from https://docs.cloudfoundry.org/cf-cli/install-go-cli.html  Hugo   Install Hugo on your laptop from https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases/download/v0.74.3/hugo_0.74.3_Windows-64bit.zip
  Update PATH to include the path to hugo executable
  Steps   Clone the FedEx GSI cookbook from Gitlab repo
git clone <cookbook repo>
  Open a command window and navigate to the cookbook directory
  Start Hugo server locally
./localserver.bat
  Check if recipes are displayed in the browser (http://localhost:1313)
  Add a new recipe or update an existing recipe(s)
  Publish the cookbook with updated recipes:
./publish
  cd <cookbook dir>/public
  Deploy the cookbook to PCF using CF cli
cf push
  Verify the cookbook with recipes is accessible at https://<pcf API endpoint>/cookbook

title: How to Create a Recipe
content:
Prerequisite  cf CLI Hugo  Install instructions cf CLI  Install cf CLI from https://docs.cloudfoundry.org/cf-cli/install-go-cli.html  Hugo  Hugo is one of the most popular open-source static site generators, that enables user content in markdown format to be rendered in HTML and other formats.
   Install Hugo on your laptop from https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases/download/v0.74.3/hugo_0.74.3_Windows-64bit.zip
  Update PATH to include the path to hugo executable
  Steps   Open a command/shell window and navigate to the cookbook directory
  Create a new recipe
â€‹	hugo new recipes/a-new-recipe.md
  always specify *.md extension for the recipe file.
  a-new-recipe.md is created in content/recipes/
    Edit recipe using any IDE or text editor
  avoid putting title of the recipe in its body as Hugo generates one from the title tag.
  to add images to a recipe, put them in static/images directory of the cookbook.
  review the header in the generated recipe to adjust the tags, summary and title.
categories = ["recipes"] tags = ["some meaningful tag1", "some meaningful tag2"] summary = "multi line summary should come here" title = "A New Recipe" date = 2020-09-01T10:55:46-05:00   be consistent with tagging. Less is more. Check existing tags by opening See All Tags link from the sidebar.
    Preview the recipe
 start the local Hugo server using ./localserver.bat access http://localhost:1313 using the browser the recipe should appear on the left under Recipes

title: Home
content: Cookbook with recipes for application modernization using cloud native foundation principles
